answer_html: \(\displaystyle \lnot Q(4) \Rightarrow \lnot P(3)\) In words this is “17 is not divisible by 3 implies that 3 is not divisible by 4”.
answer_latex:
$\displaystyle
\lnot Q(4) \Rightarrow \lnot P(3)$  In words this is \emph{``17 is not
divisible by 3 implies that 3 is not divisible by 4''}.
hints_html:
The converse of the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \Rightarrow B\end{aligned}\]

is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle B \Rightarrow A\end{aligned}\]

The contrapositive of the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A \Rightarrow B\end{aligned}\]

is

\[\begin{aligned} \lnot B \Rightarrow \lnot A\end{aligned}\]
hints_raw:
The ''converse'' of the statement
:<math>\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B
</math>
is
:<math>\displaystyle
B \Rightarrow A
</math>
The ''contrapositive'' of the statement
:<math>\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B
</math>
is
:<math>
\lnot B \Rightarrow \lnot A
</math>
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
• The statement

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle P(3) \Rightarrow Q(4)\end{aligned}\]

is “3 is divisible by 4 implies that 17 is divisible by 3”.

  • The converse is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle Q(4) \Rightarrow P(3)\end{aligned}\]

hence in words it is “17 is divisible by 3 implies that 3 is divisible by 4”.

  • The contrapositive is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lnot Q(4) \Rightarrow \lnot P(3)\end{aligned}\]

In words this is “17 is not divisible by 3 implies that 3 is not divisible by 4”.
sols_raw:
* The statement
:<math>\displaystyle
P(3) \Rightarrow Q(4)
</math>
is ''"3 is divisible by 4 implies that 17 is divisible by 3"''. 

* The '''converse''' is
:<math>\displaystyle
Q(4) \Rightarrow P(3)
</math>
hence in words it is ''"17 is divisible by 3 implies that 3 is divisible by 4"''.

* The '''contrapositive''' is 
:<math>\displaystyle
\lnot Q(4) \Rightarrow \lnot P(3)
</math>
In words this is ''"17 is not divisible by 3 implies that 3 is not divisible by 4"''.
statement_html:
For n \(\in\) N, let P(n) be the statement “n is divisible by 4”, and let Q(n) be the statement “n2 + 1 is divisible by 3”.

Write out in words the statement “P(3) \(\rightarrow\) Q(4)”, its converse, and its contrapositive.
statement_latex:
For \emph{n} $\in$ \textbf{N}, let \emph{P}(\emph{n}) be the statement
"\emph{n} is divisible by 4", and let \emph{Q}(\emph{n}) be the
statement "\emph{n}\textsuperscript{2} + 1 is divisible by 3".

Write out in words the statement "\emph{P}(3) $\rightarrow$ \emph{Q}(4)", its
converse, and its contrapositive.
statement_raw:
For ''n'' &isin; '''N''', let ''P''(''n'') be the statement "''n'' is divisible by 4", and let ''Q''(''n'') be the statement "''n''<sup>2</sup> + 1 is divisible by 3".

Write out in words the statement "''P''(3) &rarr; ''Q''(4)", its converse, and its contrapositive.
